meta.description: Calls for Proposals, Tech Conferences, and Speaking Tips
meta.author: Karl L. Hughes

post.html:
If you’re considering submitting a conference talk, but you’re not sure if it’s really worth it, read on. In this section, I’ve collected the most common reasons people cite for wanting to speak at conferences.

Developer Advocates: Professional Technical Speakers

I didn’t realize this was a job until I started speaking at conferences and met a few people who did this. “Developer Advocates” (sometimes called DevRels or Developer Evangelists) are paid to get their company’s name out into the public. It’s a lot like marketing, but with a decidedly technical bent.

Most Developer Advocates still write code, help support the products they work on, and are involved in coming up with and testing new features. Because their job is to be in the public eye, many of them are very prolific speakers.

During my first year [in Developer Relations] at Okta…I spoke 37 times, at 20 conferences, in 10 different countries. Matt Raible

While an element of their job may require speaking, many also do it for other reasons you’ll read about below.

Promote a Business or Project

“Speaking at conferences is a good way to boost my career prospects as a technology consultant.” Jason Swett

“Some of the connections I’ve made at conferences and meetups have definitely helped me land further speaking gigs and new clients.” Keanan Koppenhaver

  • “If you run a consultancy or contracting company, speaking at conferences can be an important way to find new business. If you want to work with local clients, you should focus on local events. If you sell a product to developers, then you should speak at the largest events you can.” - https://hackernoon.com/how-and-why-to-speak-at-tech-conferences-1d50a3f548e0
  • “I use open-source projects to make money. I try to contribute to some libraries also, but promoting them on stage feels like the best thing that I’m capable of doing. If something makes my life better, and some people invest their efforts and share it for free — I want to help them to gain exposure.” - https://medium.com/@tryshchenko/why-am-i-doing-public-speaking-at-tech-events-the-honest-answer-a75d80f85cfd

Help others

  • “I feel guilty about being privileged enough to have gone to a Computer Science University, so I try as much as possible to help other people get into tech, or get better at tech. Knowing I helped at least one person by being on stage and sharing my knowledge makes me feel a bit better about that.” - Alex Lakatos
  • “What I like about public speaking is that it puts me in a new place to help other people. I am thrilled that I’m providing content that people want to hear, and content that they can take something from to apply to their lives.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speakers-story-rhia-dixon/
  • “It’s really cool that the way I present something or specifically explain something can help make whatever I’m talking about click with someone in a way that it hasn’t before.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speakers-story-kara-luton/
  • “I enjoy being able to share my advice with a lot of people at once. It is like mentoring or giving advice on steroids.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speaker-molly-struve/

Meet people

  • “it’s great to be able to speak about the thing you’re interested in in front of a lot of people, because it means for the rest of the conference the other people who share your passion will come up and talk to you.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speakers-story-nicola-rushton/
  • “Speaking at conferences is a really fun way to meet other developers and get outside perspectives on things — not just outside your particular industry, but outside your own country!” - George Mandis
  • “I think it’s a lot easier to meet people when you’re the one giving the presentation because 1) people already know a topic they can discuss with you which cuts out a lot of networking small talk and 2) people come up to you instead of you having to approach them every time” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speakers-bailey-lewis/
  • “Too many speakers finish their talk and then rush off to catch a plane, or hole themselves up in a hotel room to get back on top of email. If you do this, you’re missing out on one of the most valuable aspects of an event: the networking.” - https://blog.prezi.com/speaking-at-a-conference-here-are-10-things-the-organizer-wants-you-to-keep-in-mind/

Recognition

  • “There’s something impressive about going to a city for the first time, and have people walk up and introduce themselves to me, mentioning past talks or blog posts.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speakers-story-gant-laborde/
  • People came up to me after my talk, “you were the washing machine, guy, right?”
  • “Some people have a bunch of Twitter followers and YouTube views, and this seems to make them happy. Building your public brand by speaking at conferences can be a way to work towards this.” - https://hackernoon.com/how-and-why-to-speak-at-tech-conferences-1d50a3f548e0

Travel

  • “I’ve found so far speaking is a great way to visit new places – I often take a couple of days before or after to explore the area outside of the conference hotel.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speakers-bailey-lewis/

Personal growth

  • “I’ve been incredibly fortunate to get to meet and become friends with some of my heroes in the industry as a result of speaking at conferences. That’s probably the biggest benefit for me.” - Joe Mastey
  • “Speaking also establishes your authority in your subject area, and it gives you the chance to genuinely help people learn something new. This teaching aspect is especially important to me.” - Laura Janusek
  • “I was given the opportunity to create a course for Lynda.com because I met Lynda.com staff author Ray Villalobos after we both spoke at a conference. It turned out that we were both speaking at another conference a few months later, so he made a point to check out my talk at that conference. He enjoyed it so he recommended me as a course author. Prior to that I had not even considered authoring a course, and after he sold me on the idea, it because a reality that never would have been had I not met Ray.” - John Riviello
  • “Recently I joined the Google Developer Expert program, which is something that would have very likely not happened without my conference speaking.” - George Mandis
  • “I grew up with a fatal sickness (that I still have) where I couldn’t do much and I often felt like I’d never amount to much, so in some ways, I guess I’ve been drawn to public speaking to overcompensate.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speakers-story-tejas-kumar/
  • “The more I present the more confident I become in my abilities to do so. This has helped with my social anxiety and with my ability to interact with clients or potential clients.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speakers-mike-miles/
  • “Speaking at conferences has definitely helped to improve my presentation skills. I am more confident in speaking in front of groups of people who I don’t know whereas before I would get nervous and my anxiety levels would go through the roof.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speakers-rizwan-javaid/
  • “you can be introverted, awkward, and socially anxious, and still be a great conference speaker and get a ton of benefit from doing it.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speakers-eva-penzeymoog/

Finding jobs

  • ”[Meetups] can also be a great way to learn more about companies in your area, or to get a leg up in your next local job search.” - https://hackernoon.com/how-and-why-to-speak-at-tech-conferences-1d50a3f548e0
  • “During job interviews, I’ve had interviewers tell me how much they loved my talks!” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speaker-anjuan-simmons/

Thrilling

  • “Public speaking is very energizing, probably similar to drugs, but with no bad side-effects!” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speaker-nicolas-frankel/

Passion

  • “These are real people who are being controlled, beaten, and murdered - and we in tech have a role to play in preventing it from happening.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speakers-eva-penzeymoog/
  • “I’ve always been fascinated by the ability of human speech to change the world, and I hope that my public speaking is a small brick in the enormous wall of humanity’s ongoing attempt to make ourselves better.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speaker-anjuan-simmons/

Learn new things

  • “it’s an excuse to learn and play with new technology. I wouldn’t have become passionate about the OpenAPI spec if a conference hadn’t given me a chance to speak on it for example. And because my day job tends to focus more on boring tech that works, giving conference talks lets me experiment with stuff I know we wouldn’t touch at work.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speakers-story-matthew-trask/
  • “When I submit a talk proposal it’s usually on a topic that I am not an expert on, but one that I am interested in learning more about. I then have a motivator to deep dive into the topic to learn about it.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speakers-mike-miles/

  • “Building demos can really help you with learning the ins and outs on a topic and you never know what you may uncover.” - https://www.cfpland.com/blog/speaker-taelur-alexis/

    • “While writing talks are a huge time commitment, there is nothing quite like explaining a concept to others to help crystalize it in your mind.” - Laurie Barth

frontmatter.title: Why Speak? The Reasons People Get on Stage
